_prev_prog_3.Description:
Woodspur Operations LLC has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR

Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8,

Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials), and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

Woodspur Operations LLC has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR

Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8,

Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials), and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Woodspur Farms has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Woodspur Farms, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Woodspur Farms has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

System 1                      Anhydrous Ammonia                13,000

System 2                      Anhydrous Ammonia                13,000

System 3                      Anhydrous Ammonia                 3,400



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. 

Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedure

s in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



Woodspur Farms operates a commercial cold storage and processing facility for dates and other fruits in Coachella, CA. The facility has (3) three ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:



Process 1

Rooms 3-5

Bin Room

(2) Hallways

Ingredient Room

Machinery Room (not in use)

Electrical Room (not in use)

Falling Film Chiller

Precool Rooms 1-3 (not in use)



Process 2

Rooms 10-12

Bare Pipe Coil Ice Builder



Process 3

Loading Dock

Rooms 13-15

The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators for the flooded operations. The refrigeration machinery is contained within, directly above, or outside the machinery rooms. A partial list of system components includes:



Process 1

Machinery Room 1

(2) Reciprocating compressors

(1) Screw compressors

(3) Oil separators

(1) Recirculator

(3) Ammonia pumps

(1) Accumulator 

(1) Falling film chiller

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling suspended)

Condenser Area 1

(1) Evaporative condenser

(1) High pressure receiver

Electrical Room

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling suspended)

Bin Room

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (floor-mounted)

(1) Accumulator

Room 3

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling suspended)

Room 4

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (floor-mounted)

(1) Accumulator

Room 5

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (floor-mounted)

(1) Accumulator

Ingredient Room

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (c

eiling suspended)

Hallway 1

(6) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling suspended)

Hallway 2

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling suspended)

Decommissioned/Abandoned Equipment

The following equipment has been valved off, but remains connected to Process 1:

Precool 1 Evaporator

Precool 2 Evaporator

Precool 3 Evaporators 1-3

Old High Pressure Receiver



Process 2

Machinery Room 2

(5) Reciprocating compressors

(5) Oil separators

Machinery Room 2 Roof

(1) Evaporative condenser

(1) High pressure receiver

Recirculator Room

(1) Recirculator

(2) Ammonia pumps

(1) Oil Pot

Pit Area

(1) Bare pipe coil

(1) Surge drum

Room 10 (Staging Room)

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling suspended)

Room 11 (Storage Area)

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling suspended)

Room 12 (Precool Room)

(9) Air-cooling evaporators (floor-mounted)



Process 3

Machinery Room 3

(1) Reciprocating compressors

(1) Screw compressors

(2) Oil separators

(1) Suction accumulator

(1) Transfer vessel

(1) Oil pot

Condenser Area 3

(2) Evaporative condensers

(1) Controlled pressure receiver

(2) Pilot receivers

Plant 3 Loading Dock

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling suspended)

Room 13

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling suspended)

Room 14

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling suspended)

Room 15 

(4) Air Cooling Evaporators (ceiling suspended)



Room 4, Room 5, Bin Room, the falling film chiller, and the bare pipe coil operate as follows: pumped liquid from the recirculators (Room 4, Room 5, Bin Room, and falling film chiller) or high pressure liquid from the receiver (bare pipe coil) is piped to each area, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator. From each accumulator, low pressure liquid is circulated through an evaporator. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator. The suction gas is returned from the accumulator through a suction return lin

e back to the recirculator or main suction accumulator. From the recirculator or main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.



The Machinery Room, Electrical Room, Ingredient Room, Hallways, and Rooms 10-12 operate as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a series of liquid feed solenoid valves, expansion valves, and into the liquid recirculators. From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into the evaporator. Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporators. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculators. The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculators and the gas is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receivers.



Plant 3 cold rooms (Rooms 13-15 and Loading Dock) operate as follows: liquid from the controlled pressure receiver is piped to the evaporators, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into the evaporator. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form a low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the main suction accumulator. The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the accumulator and the gas is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas. The high pressu

re discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the controlled pressure receiver.



Each system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. 



An emergency control box is installed in Plant 2 and Plant 3 on the exterior wall of the refrigeration machinery rooms. Each emergency control box contains three valves. The high and low side of the system each have a valve that would discharge to atmosphere. The connecting pipe between the high and low side has one equalizer valve that would equalize the system.

All three (3) ammonia refrigeration systems at Woodspur Farms consist of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping within their respective systems. The systems are neither connected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the refrigeration systems at Woodspur Farms are treated as three (3) separate processes.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Woodspur Farms has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and har copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Woodspur Farms facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most

of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.  



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Woodspur Farms has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Woodspur Farms's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we

will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Woodspur Farms has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Woodspur Farms continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Woodspur Farms's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Woodspur Farms's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Woodspur Farms has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Woodspur Farms has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Woodspur Farms now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Woodspur Farms employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Woodspur Farms will continue to maintain ove
rall plant worker and public safety.
